name: Miami
fun_fact: Fun fact: Miami is the only major U.S. city founded by a woman - Julia Tuttle, the 'Mother of Miami,' convinced railroad tycoon Henry Flagler to extend his tracks south in 1896 by sending him fresh orange blossoms after a freeze destroyed crops up north

hero_dishes.name: Ropa Vieja
hero_dishes.description: Shredded flank steak slow-braised in a savory tomato sauce with bell peppers, onions, and olives - literally translates to 'old clothes' because the meat shreds look like tattered fabric
hero_dishes.origin_story: Cuba's national dish, brought to Miami by waves of Cuban exiles since the 1960s. Legend says a poor man tore up and cooked his own clothes, which miraculously turned into this stew. The Freedom Tower (1925) served as Miami's 'Ellis Island of the South' for these refugees
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Versailles Restaurant (the iconic spot with mirrors and chandeliers), La Carreta on Calle Ocho (the original location), El Cristo Restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Cuban Sandwich (Cubano)
hero_dishes.description: Roasted pork, ham, Swiss cheese, pickles, and mustard pressed between Cuban bread until the cheese melts and the crust crisps to golden perfection
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born in Tampa's cigar factories, perfected in Miami's Little Havana. The bread is crucial - baked with lard and topped with palmetto leaves for a soft interior and crispy crust. Miami's version uses salami, Tampa's doesn't - locals still argue about this
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Versailles Restaurant, La Carreta, Old's Havana Cuban Bar & Cocina on Calle Ocho

hero_dishes.name: Stone Crab Claws
hero_dishes.description: Chilled stone crab claws served with tangy mustard sauce - only the claws are harvested, then the crab is released to regrow them
hero_dishes.origin_story: Exclusive to South Florida waters, this delicacy has been Miami's signature seafood since 1913 when Joe Weiss opened Joe's Stone Crab. Season runs October 15 to May 15. Miami is bordered by two national parks - Biscayne and Everglades - making it a seafood paradise
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Joe's Stone Crab (the original since 1913, expect 2-hour waits), Truluck's, Garcia's Seafood

hero_dishes.name: Vaca Frita
hero_dishes.description: Crispy shredded beef marinated in lime and garlic, pan-fried until the edges char and caramelize, topped with raw onions
hero_dishes.origin_story: Cuban comfort food meaning 'fried cow' - originally a way to repurpose leftover boiled beef. The key is getting the meat crispy while keeping it tender inside, a technique perfected in Little Havana kitchens
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mojitos Calle 8 (in the striking blue building since 2001), El Cuban Diner (new 1950s-themed spot opened Oct 2025), Versailles

signature_drinks.name: Cuban Coffee (Cafecito)
signature_drinks.description: Espresso whipped with sugar until it forms a golden foam (espuma), served in tiny cups - intensely sweet and strong enough to wake the dead
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Stand at ventanitas (walk-up windows) along Calle Ocho, knock it back in one shot while gossiping with neighbors. La Carreta's CafÃ© con Leche is legendary - half espresso, half steamed milk. Never sit down for this, always standing

signature_drinks.name: Mojito
signature_drinks.description: White rum muddled with fresh mint, lime juice, sugar, and topped with soda water - born in Havana, perfected in Miami
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sipped slowly on outdoor patios during Miami's eternal summer. Order one at Mojitos Calle 8 or Ball & Chain, the historic jazz club where Billie Holiday once performed. Locals insist on fresh mint, never mint syrup

food_culture_notes: Calle Ocho (8th Street) in Little Havana is Miami's Cuban heartbeat - every March, the Calle Ocho Festival draws 1 million people
Ventanitas (walk-up coffee windows) are everywhere - grab your cafecito and chat with strangers
Miami has the world's largest concentration of Art Deco buildings (800+) - many 1930s structures have hidden features indicating illegal gambling from mob days
The white sand on Miami Beach isn't natural - it was imported from the Bahamas to combat erosion

landmarks: Art Deco buildings on Ocean Drive (pastel colors, geometric shapes)
Freedom Tower (1925 - Miami's Ellis Island of the South)
Calle Ocho street signs and murals in Little Havana
atmosphere: tropical humidity and palm tree shadows
live salsa music spilling from open doorways
neon-lit Art Deco facades at dusk
colors: pastel pink and mint green (Art Deco)
